Osaka is the second largest city in Japan, but a lot more energetic and historical compared to the largest city, Tokyo. There are many historical sites to visit, and there are also countless amounts of cultural and local places to visit. This tour will include many of the cultural places in Osaka. There are two different options, so please pick the one you would like to visit depending on your interest. Here are some information about the places you will visit. ・Dotonbori: Dotonbori is a very famous shopping district in Osaka. Here, you will find numerous restaurants, shops and cultural sites. It is very popular street for people to eat and walk. It will be very bright and loud at night, and you will see why people like spending their time in the city during the night in Japan. ・Kuishinbo Yokocho: Kuishinbo Yokocho is an indoor-food district made for people to taste and know the fascinating food culture in Osaka. The model of the building represents the 1970s, when the traditional working-class neighborhood were in bloom. You can eat various different Japanese food here. strIntroduction: This tour will take you to the southern part of Kyoto where your professional guide will introduce you to some of the most fascinating historical spots of Japan's old capital. First you'll visit the nursery Koju-en, where you will have the chance to see plenty of masterful bonsai art pieces and learn more about the tradition of bonsai making in Kyoto. After that you'll continue to Toji Temple - the oldest one in Tokyo and a designated UNESCO World Cultural Heritage Site. This temple was built in the Heian period and the famous Buddhist monk Kobo Daishi (Kukai) was its head priest for many years. Here you can see Japan's tallest Buddhist pagoda which rises above all other buildings around. Finally, your guide will take you to Fushimi Inari Shrine - the central of all Inari shrines which worship the fox spirit around the country. The most attractive feature of Fushimi Inari are the hundreds vermillion gates which continue in the forest up the mountain. At the end of this half-day tour you will have seen some of the most interesting places related to Kyoto's history and culture.
strTitle: Explore the highlights of southern Kyoto in a half-day tour!

strIntroduction: Daisenin temple is a Buddhist temple, one of fourteen autonomous branches of the Rinzai school of Japanese Zen. It is located in Kita-ku, Kyoto, Japan. The "mountain name" (sango), by which it is known, is Ryūhōzan. In this activity, you will be able to experience Zen meditation with a traditional Japanese green tea at Daisenin temple. Furthermore, you can also visit their famous and beautiful Zen gardens "Dokuzatei" and "Kanmintei", as well as authentic Japanese tea rooms. strTitle: Zen Meditation at Daisenin Temple with Tasty Green Tea.

strIntroduction: Kyoto has a large cultural legacy coming from its 1200 year-long history. We offer special private tours in Kyoto at affordable costs. Our government-licensed guides will meet you at your hotel, and take you not only to major tourists' spots but also to lesser-known alleys and markets. At the end of the tour, you will agree that the best feature of Kyoto city is the mixture of the new and the old! Sanjusangen-do ↓ Kiyomizu Temple ↓ Sannenzaka ↓ Gion ↓ Nishiki Market ↓ End of tour (Tour guide will assist you how to get to the subway station or the nearby bus stop for your next visiting spot or your hotel) ==Sanjusangen-do== The main hall of Sanjusangen-do contains 1,001 wooden statues of Juichimen- Senju- Kannon, "11-faced, thousand -armed Buddhist goddess of mercy". The principal image, the seated statue of Senju Kannon, sits in the center of the collection. These statues exhibit an extraordinary level of craftsmanship from the Kamakura period, representing the essence of Buddhist art. Although the Kannon Bodhisattvas all look almost identical, there seems to be the statue resembling yourself among them. == Kiyomizu Temple == This temple predates the foundation of Kyoto and has had millions of pilgrims ever since. It is designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site with over 30 structures, including a huge wooden veranda in front of the main hall that juts out over the cliff and provides you a panoramic view of Kyoto. There is a famous expression: that states "You must jump off the stage of Kiyomizu." It means that you should take the plunge to make your dreams come true. == Sannenzaka == This sloped path leading to Kiyomizu temple was originally paved with stones in about 808 AD and may be the most trod-upon street in Kyoto. It is lined with old wooden houses running restaurants and shops selling pottery, artworks and other traditional goods. You may come across young women dressed in kimono and feel as though you had traveled back in time to the days of 300 years ago. == Gion == Gion is an entertainment district beautifully lined with traditional town houses and restaurants, you will see encounter geiko and maiko, professional entertainers trained in traditional Japanese dance and music, including the playing the shamisen (like a three-stringed guitar) and singing. They can be seen wearing, beautiful, elaborate kimonos as they walk to and from appointments. Some Japanese entertainment, like kabuki, is performed solely by men, but in Gion, all the entertainment is provided by women. After graduating from Jr. High School, girls enter a preparatory program to become maiko, apprentices of geiko. They learn skills such as dance, music, tea ceremony and flower arrangement to become the ideal traditional entertainer. ==Nishiki Market== If you need a break from temple hopping, Nishiki Market is a great place to visit. Located in the center of the town, Nishikikoji-dori, 400 meters long, is a street lined with around 130 shops selling Kyoto's specialties, such as Kyoto vegetables, dried and pickled foods, fish, and more. That's why it is called "the kitchen of Kyoto". The variety of foods on display is staggering and the frequent cries of Irashaimase (Welcome!) are heart-warming.
strTitle: Explore Kyoto: Gion, Kiyomizu, Nishiki Market - Private Tour

strIntroduction: Come experience the high life in Ginza! Ginza is a district in Tokyo known for its many department stores, boutiques, restaurants, and coffee houses. In this activity, I will take you to the best of Ginza based on your interests. Some suggestions for your tour will include: Shopping: Ginza is a shopper's paradise with many Japanese brands and most major international brands. "Ginbura": Ginbura is a word used in japan to describe the act of walking around Ginza on the weekends when parts of its streets close to traffic. You'll also see that many street performers appear for "Ginbura". Art: There are a number of popular art galleries around the Ginza area including Galleria Grafica Tokyo, Shiseido Gallery, and Vanilla Gallery. There are also kabuki theaters and delicious upscale restaurants you might want to visit. Contact me for more information.
strTitle: Guided Tour of Ginza

strIntroduction: The Japanese kimono is one of the world’s most recognizable traditional garments. However, the kimono is extremely complex and there is a specific step-by-step process to properly put one on. The friendly professionals will assist you in trying on your kimono, making it extremely easy and hassle free. Come and try a piece of history and experience wearing a traditional kimono for yourself! After putting on your Kimono, you can walk around Ginza and show off your beautiful kimono to the world. These are the options that you can choose from: -Kimono Experience 30minutes Try wearing a kimono for fun! Bring your camera! You can go outside about 15minutes for take some pictures. -Kimono Walking 120minutes Try wearing a kimono and take a walk around Ginza! -Formal Kimono 180minutes Experience wearing Japanese wedding garments!
strTitle: Walk Around in a Kimono in Ginza, Tokyo

strIntroduction: We(one of our family member) will guide you to the tea field at the top of a mountain and tell you all about the history and production of this pesticide-free organic tea which began in 1975. If the weather is nice, you can enjoy an scenic view of of Mount Fuji, Suruga Bay, Izu Peninsula and the town below from the tea field. You will stay with a family of tea farmers in their house. Dinner will comprise traditional dishes with plenty of seasonal chemical-free vegetables. Let's talk about traditional agriculture, nature, community, and the culture of Japan over dinner. On the second day, there will be tour around our tea factory in the morning. This factory started domestic tea making since the year 2000. They imported the first professional tea roller machines from Sri Lanka to produce authentic domestic tea. You will have a chance to taste several types of tea including black tea and green tea. We will also introduce the best way to make good tea for each type of tea. Time will be from 3pm to 10am of the next day. Deepen your knowledge on Japanese tea. Experience the traditional lifestyle of farmers living in organic tea production lands. *Please note that due to seasonal harvesting we won't be able to host you everyday, so please contact us before you make any reservation. Do not hestitate to send us a message too if you have further questions with regards to the tour. Thank you for your kind understanding.
strTitle: Stay in the Land of Organic Tea and Learn Tea Culture

strIntroduction: Since the Edo period (1603-1868) Asakusa has been the most popular tourist site in Tokyo. Today, Asakusa remains the No.1 destination for foreign tourists. Come join us in this private walking tour in Asakusa! Nakamise street is the oldest shopping arcade in Tokyo, and is always bustling with visitors enroute to Senso-ji Temple. Be taken back in time in Dempoin Street, where you can enjoy the atmosphere of the Edo period. Take in a ninja show at the Hanayashiki Amusement Park, or enjoy a ride on a traditional rickshaw. To really get a sense of Japanese life, why not visit a kimono shop where you will be able to try on a traditional kimono? Then take a walk in your kimono to the nearby Taiko Drum Museum. Afterwards take a rest in one of Asakusa's many delicious restaurants or browse it's souvenir shops to make this experience one you will remember. Our guide is happy to pick you up from your hotel if you book hotel pick up option, but please note all transfer expenses for this tour are excluded from the online price. You can head to the tour's departure point by taxi, or Tokyo's excellent rail system. Photo Credit: http://flic.kr/p/72zKCQ, http://flic.kr/p/aDXPcU, http://flic.kr/p/95SHj3, http://flic.kr/p/8kFc6K http://flic.kr/p/FC3Vi
strTitle: Visit Sensoji! Enjoy Asakusa Private Walking Tour!

strIntroduction: The Tsukiji Sushi Workshop is lead by veterans of the Tsukiji Fish Market and sushi masters who have been pursuing Japanese cuisine for many years in Asakusa and Tsukiji. What we at the Tsukiji Sushi Workshop are offering is aimed at people wanting to know not only how to prepare sushi, but everything from learning about the procurement of ingredients to presentation. ----------------------------------------------------- - Sushi masters profile Morita Morita-san spent 3 years in Milan gaining experience with Mediterranean seafood. In order to deepen his understanding of seafood cuisine, in 2004 he started working in Tsukiji and has been hard at work ever since. “You have to be quick here in Tsukiji. Since freshness is so important, everyone in Tsukiji gets up in the early hours before dawn and shops will start to close soon after lunch. And of course, this need for speed is one of the reasons behind the origins of sushi. We hope to share our passion for Sushi and Japanese cuisine with you!” ----------------------------------------------------- Noji At the age of 23, Noji-san started his career as a chef at the century-old Ryotei, a famous establishment of fine Japanese dining. Not completely satisfied, when he turned 33 he moved to Tsukiji to rediscover the roots of Japanese cuisine. And now, he is the owner of his own restaurant. “Tsukiji is a town of change. Adapting to both season and age, it is constantly striving to provide the perfect ingredients for cuisine. For chefs like me, it really is a treasure trove – if I come here I can get hold of ingredients I can’t get my hands on anywhere else. I look forward to sharing my experience of Tsukiji with you!” ----------------------------------------------------- On the morning of the workshop, we will come and pick you up from the local train station (Tsukiji Station, on the Tokyo Metro Hibiya Line) at 9:00 am. On a typical day, after a brief round of introductions we will show you around to the Tsukiji Inner and Outer Fish Market. Here, we will show you how to select delicious, seasonal ingredients for making sushi (in Japanese this process is called “Mekiki”, literally meaning “judgement by eye”) – and after this, under the expert guidance of our sushi chef you will finally get to try your hands at preparing sushi! At the end of it all, everyone will have the chance to savor the delicious meal you’ve just prepared. For more details about the itinerary, please check out the picture.
strTitle: Tsukiji Sushi InsiderWorkshop

strIntroduction: Teaching Kimono lovers how to wear a Kimono as well as sharing the Japanese tradition and culture has been my joy and pleasure. You'll be able to wear a traditional Japanese Kimono on your own in only three lessons! Lessons will be taught in my house in Meguro Tokyo, about 5 minute walk from JR Meguro station. I can teach in both Japanese and English. 1st Lesson: Nagajuban under-kimono and kimono robe 2nd Lesson: How to tie the Nagoya obi sash 3rd Lesson: How to tie the obijime belt and obiage scarf I highly recommend that you attend these lessons once in two weeks so that you have time to practice at home after each class. You are also encouraged to bring your own kimono set. However, if you don't own a kimono set, I can lend you mine or bring you Kimono shopping in the shops in Meguro or Asakusa.
strTitle: Learn to Wear a Traditional Kimono in Meguro, Tokyo

strIntroduction: The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office is located 10 minutes from Shinjuku station by foot. Many travelers may not be aware that the night view from the building is stunningly beautiful as you are able to get a panoramic view of Tokyo's night skyline. On top of that, entry is free of charge! There are shops there selling souvenirs as well. However, Shinjuku station is so huge that even the local Japanese might get lost in the maze of buildings of exits. Only those who are extremely familiar with Shinjuku will be able to find their way around. I will guide you from Shinjuku station to The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office. Along the way, I will introduce some famous buildings in the vicinity. When we come back to Shinjuku, I will show you around the neon‐lit streets. If you want to go shopping, or play at a game center etc, I can introduce you to some highly recommended places. An afternoon tour option is also available, but do let me know in advance. Looking forward to meeing you! Let's explore exciting Shinjuku together! Photo Credit: http://flic.kr/p/5STREW
strTitle: Enjoy an Awesome Night View of Shinjuku

strIntroduction: Japanese tattoo is now established as one of the most renowned tattoo styles, and considered a form of modern art the world over. Most images used in Japanese tattoos have meaning and purpose, and it is hard to find an artist outside of Japan with full understanding of these. I have been tattooing for over 10 years in Japan and have specifically studied the Japanese style (Irezumi). In this experience you can get a real Japanese tattoo by a Japanese tattoo artist while staying in Tokyo. (I always use a tattoo machine, rather than 'hand-poking' my tattoos) Japanese style tattoos often depict subjects covering large areas of the body and take a lot of time, but you can also get a onepoint Japanese tattoo. The price will vary according to the size, place and detail of the design. Please check the price example which is listed below. Example prices: Onepoint tattoo/business card size is around 20,000 Yen; postcard size from 30,000 Yen. A sleeve or back piece will be charged for the outline first, and then shading: a chest or half sleeve outline is 30,000 Yen, full sleeve outline 50,000 Yen, back piece outline from 50,000 Yen. Then shading is 10,000 Yen per hour. When you book you'll pay 10,000 Yen upfront through the Voyagin website. Then you can pay the rest of the balance at the studio, since the total price will depend on the size and design of your tattoo. There's no need to pay it all in advance for a big piece - you pay each time you get tattooed. Example times: A postcard size tattoo takes around 2-3 hours, and a half sleeve takes about 15-20 hours, but it varies according to detail and color. One session can be up to 8 hours. Available every day, but please message me before booking.
strTitle: Get Tattooed in Ueno, Tokyo!

strIntroduction: <On the Day of the Photo Shoot> The photo session lasts from 1.15 to 3.0 hours, depending on your selected plans and options. strIntroduction: Kyoto's unique charm attracts international visitors all year round, but the city is particularly busy during the spring period when thousands of sakura cherry trees blossom everywhere and create a unique festive atmosphere! Local people gather in the parks for traditional hanami (cherry tree appreciation) picnics, or take a pleasure boat along the water canals under the sakura trees. The feeling of fresh spring surrounds the little streets of Kyoto and makes the city particularly attractive and beautiful! In this guided tour you will visit some of Kyoto's best and most famous sakura cherry tree blossoming spots while also seeing impressive temples along the way. Your guide will tell you a lot of interesting information about Kyoto's past, history, traditions and meaning of the hanami picnic practices. Join this seasonal tour and see all the great sakura spots in one day without the need to worry about making your itineraries and researching information in advance. Here is a list of the places you will visit during the tour: 1. The Philosopher's Path: Undoubtedly Kyoto's most famous sakura blossoms spot! There are literally hundreds of sakura cherry trees along the canal path which connects Ginkakuji (the Silver Pavilion) with Nanzenji Temple. The entire path is colored in pale pink in early April and becomes one of the best places to have a pleasant walk under the sakura trees. 2. Heian Shrine: This is one of the newest shrines in Kyoto, built around the beginning of the 20th century to celebrate 1100 years of Kyoto's establishment as a Japanese capital. The shrine has spacious grounds and a beautiful garden famous for its weeping sakura cherry trees which blossom in full around mid-April. 3. Okazaki Canal: Take a sakura viewing boat and enjoy the beauty of the cherry trees which blossom right next to the canal. Appreciating the beauty of the sakura trees from a river boat is one of the best experiences in Japan around early April. 4. Maruyama Park: This park is situated next to Yasaka Shrine and is Kyoto's most popular hanami picnic spot during the sakura blossoms period. There are many food stalls and tables prepared for visitors during early April. The giant weeping sakura tree in the middle of the park is illuminated in the evening to create a special night atmosphere. Besides the above spots you will also visit the Silver Pavilion, Nanzenji Temple, Eikando Temple and Yasaka Shrine. All of Kyoto's temples are more attractive during the sakura season, so don't miss the opportunity to join this unforgettable tour!
strTitle: See Kyoto's best sakura cherry blossom spots!

strIntroduction: ***To book on a weekday, click "Contact the Host" and message us with your preferred date*** Hello friends! Got no plan for the last day? Create your own lovely Japanese home decor to bring home!! A professional tole painting teacher, Fukuko is going to teach how to make a Japanese-style home decor at a lovely, cozy art room in the good old east side of Tokyo. In this lesson, you will learn - How to draw basic Japanese patterns on the wooden item (rabbit/gold fish) - How to write your name or your favorite English word in Japanese and also add it to the decor The cost of materials are all included! You can take it home on that day. This decor can also be hanged on the wall. The background pattern will not be hand painted, but a pasted Japanese fabric. (You can choose one from a various selection of fabrics we have!) This is a fun, creative activity! Join us and let's have a great time making a decor together! :)

strIntroduction: Learn about the different aspects of Japanese culture all in the comfort of a local home in Tokyo, Japan. On this all-in-one experience, learn the techniques used in Japanese cooking in a Japanese style home kitchen and savour the flavours of a traditional Japanese dish, of your choice! Also, in this all inclusive cultural experience you will learn the art of Shodo (traditional writing of Kanji/Hiragana/Katakana with an authentic calligraphy-brush).You can get your work as a gift after you write your favorite letter on a fancy paper! Learn the traditional folding art of origami (make a ninja star, crane, and a handy box, all using a simple piece of Japanese origami). But that's not all, you will also learn Furoshiki an every day practice of cloth wrapping of about anything! Take home your origami creations, and furoshiki as a souvenir! Finish off with a Matcha tea party with Wagashi (Japanese confectionery). ※Please let me know in advance if you have allergy or religious food restrictions. ※Availability : Start from 10am for 4.5～5.5 hours on weekdays Children under 6yrs with parents are free of charge.

strIntroduction: Meet Japan's or perhaps the world's last samurai in Kyoto! Compared to the one you may have seen in the movie "The Last Samurai", this one is the real deal. If you are interested in learning the art of Bushido and having a chilled-out night after the show, this tour is definitely the right choice for you! Joe Okada, also known as the last samurai, is one of world's best known sword entertainers. Not only that, but he is also the eldest licensed English-speaking guide in Japan! He will gladly speak with you about the art of samurai. This is the schedule for the activity: 6:00 pm~ The theatre opens with 1 welcome drink. Enjoy the evening samurai show at the samurai theatre, then watch the master flaunting his 53 years of samurai experience. 7:00 pm~ Q&A Time + Sword Demonstration. 7:30pm~ After the show,Samurai Bar will open.Joe will be your delightful host and serves you local food and drink for 1 hour. Check Samurai Okada's availability (schedules are subject to Joe's availability)
strTitle: Watch an Evening Samurai show in Kyoto with The Last Samurai

strIntroduction: The holiday which feels nature with the heart and the body in Hokkaido I show the nature in which Eastern HOKKAIDO is not much known. Please feel with the heart and the body the nature which on the usual tour cannot be touched easily. Awesome, Kushiro Marshland ! Deep emotions, excitement and lasting impressions! Words can't describe the beauty of these spectacular natural wetlands. Come and feel for yourself the beauty and wonder of the natural surroundings found in the Kushiro wetlands! strIntroduction: The cuisine of Okinawa is famous for the variety that is offers. Our guide will take you the local restaurants to try soba, tempura, truly delicious sweets, and more! strIntroduction: Explore Osaka Central Wholesale Market with our government licensed guide. After enjoying shopping various fish including fresh tuna at the market, you will be invited to a private house and then have a chance to learn how to make three kinds of sushi. Osaka Kizu Wholesale Market: Osaka Kizu Wholesale Market is one of the most famous markets of Osaka Wholesale market. The market was re-launched in 2010, and with more than 300-year history, it has supported the restaurants and retail stores very well for a long time. Osaka Kizu Wholesale Market, which is also known as the “kitchen” of Osaka, is very famous for its food-loving culture. When it dawns, several thousands tons of food stuffs from all over Japan and from abroad, are dealt within around 2 hours. Our government licensed guide will escort participants around market, safely in a small group, mainly looking over the fish market which has 180 intermediate wholesalers to handle fresh fish. Outside the market, the shops which sell vegetables, fruit, pickles and other ingredients can be visited if you like. After purchasing tuna and other ingredients, participants will visit a private residence. The guide will give you information about Japanese culture and everyday life in Osaka during transfer by public transportation. Sushi Making at Home: The sushi making will be explained and instructed easily and clearly by the guide who is well acquainted with sushi-making. Learn to prepare "maki sushi"(rolled sushi), "gunkan maki"(sushi rice wrapped with a strip of seaweed and topped with soft ingredients) and "nigiri sushi"(sushi rice topped with a slice of raw fish). The beautiful sushi designs created are sure to delight and appeal to guests of all ages, especially children. The sushi making at a typical private home will surely be an once-in-a lifetime Japanese experience and a great opportunity to experience and enjoy daily life in Osaka, which includes Osaka dialects with lively atmosphere! Sushi Party: After making sushi and arranging them beautifully, it's time for a sushi party and to enjoy eating together. Following the tour, participants may take with them the utensils used in the cooking lesson. Impress your family and friends with your new sushi making skills by throwing a sushi party at home – the perfect Japanese souvenir! Our guide will take you to the nearest station in order to provide the customer an easy access to the hotel or to the next destination. Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/stewart/2473047026/
strTitle: Private Fish Market Walking and Sushi making in Osaka

strIntroduction: Roppongi is one of the art spot in Tokyo. There are three main museums and some galleries. In this tour you will.... (1) watching art at a museum I'll pick up the best exhibition to show you among three museum in Tokyo. Usually I would like to choose contemporary art exhibition, but if you prefer trad I could arrange for you. [Mori art museum] http://www.mori.art.museum/jp/index.html [Suntory museum] http://www.suntory.co.jp/sma/ [National art gallery] http://www.nact.jp/ (2)watching art at a gallery Also let's go to contemporary art gallery in Roppongi. http://www.zen-foto.jp/ http://www.takaishiigallery.com/en/ http://www.londongallery.co.jp/ http://www.otafinearts.com/ja/ http://www.wako-art.jp/ (3) see a beautiful view of Tokyo from the 53rd floor (4) eat authentic Japanese food at a Japanese style restaurant to finish our tour Let's discover Tokyo art in Roppongi together!
strTitle: Roppongi Art Tour

strIntroduction: Get a hands on experience in the process and learn about the traditional Japanese dessert, called Wagashi. Here you will visit a family run shop that has been in operation for more than 140 years! Okinaya is a sweets shop that specializes in the preparation of exquisite and graceful Wagashi reflecting the seasonal beauty and splendid culture of Japan. Founded in 1865, Okinaya is dedicated to producing and selling Wagashi for traditional tea ceremonies, gifts, and for home use. The shop was burned down during an air raid during World War II, but emerged from the devastation and resumed their business in the same location, providing the comfort Wagashi brings to people. The shop has served their sweets to many people from different walks of life including; Ayu-gashi, a signature sweet of Gifu Ukai (known for cormorant fishing), and several times for the Emperor and the Imperial Family when Their Majesties visited Gifu. The current President of Okinaya, Masanao Hayashi, is the 5th generation owner of the shop. In this program you can... 1. Learn about the history and cultural importance of Wagashi in Japan. 2. Get a hands on experience of the final processes of making 3 kinds of sweets.
strTitle: Experience the World of Wagashi

strIntroduction: First come first serve! We will give 50% discount to the first 5 reservations made! ----------------------------- Have you ever wondered how people make pearl necklaces? Have you ever wanted to make your own pearl necklace? There are many shops that sell pearl necklaces but there are rarely any shops where you can experience making your own, original necklace! Every pearl has its own distinct shape and color. You will be picking pearls of your choice and will be piecing them together! You will have your original necklace made with your favorite color and design! We have many visitors to our showroom from Japan and abroad, and we can accommodate up to 10 people at once, so we invite you to bring your friends! You can make necklaces with Akoya pearls or with Freshwater pearls. In addition to this collection, we have several other kinds of pearls. The Akoya pearl size is approximately 6 mm to 8 mm, which is a cute and lovely size. Its soft, pink color will brighten up your skin. The Tahitian Black pearl is also popular amongst our customers. It's deep black color, will give you an elegant and exclusive impression. Choose the pearl you want! We want you to feel relaxed in our showroom, and we hope you will make your necklace with ease, with our pearl necklace supporters around. Our experts are all qualified and are more than happy to show you how to make a beautiful pearl necklace. The president of this company has been devoting his life to pearls for over 30 years. strIntroduction: In this activity designed for beginners, you will learn how to dye and draw using a traditional Japanese method called "Yuzen-zomé" on a handkerchief or coaster. Your instructor is Kiichiro Fujiki, who has been a Yuzen dyer for 55 years and now collaborates with Disney on projects. He has also dyed and designed many delicate but vibrant kimonos for films. To give you a brief history of the craft, "Yuzen-zomé" was originally started by Yuzensai Miyazaki about 300 years ago in Kyoto. The beautiful and elaborate Yuzen-dyed kimonos were a colorful element of Geisha culture during the Edo era. Today, "Yuzen-zomé" is still very popular and is sought after by many people. In this beginner's course, you will be able to make your own handkerchief or coaster. You can use your favorite colors to express yourself. -- All finished products will serve as your souvenir of this unique experience.
strTitle: Experience the Traditional Way of Dyeing Fabric in Tokyo

strTitle: Chat with Japanese Locals in English!

strIntroduction: Buddhist Zen meditation, or Zazen, is a type of meditation that calms the body and mind, and helps one gain enlightenment. Gifu Zenko-ji temple was founded in 1582 and was used to enshrine Japan's first Buddha statue from China. This statue, called Ikko Sanzon Amida Nyorai, was the symbol of Shinshu Zenko-ji temple and was worshiped by people from all walks of life due to its auspiciousness. During the Warring States Period (1493 - 1590), each feudal warlord scrambled to own this statue, either to protect their land or to symbolize their power. One of these warlords was Oda Nobunaga, who almost unified Japan during this warring period. When he conquered Gifu Castle, he brought this statue along to Gifu to pray for the peace of the town. After his death, the state changed hands among several warlords before returning to Shinshu Zenko-ji. Years later, the Zenko-ji hall was established to commemorate Shinshu Zenko-ji Nyorai. In this tour, you will: -Learn the proper procedures when visiting a temple -Practice zen meditation -Understand Japanese history and culture -Increase your concentration and relief stress & anxiety.
strTitle: Practice Zazen at Zenko-ji Temple in Gifu

strIntroduction: On this experience, learn about and go shopping for authentic Japanese pottery! Nagara Tobo Ceramics was established in 2003 by the Master Potter, Shinji Majita. Specializing in Minoyaki style pottery, he has inherited and maintains the traditional techniques such as Shino and Oribe. The Master creates products ranging from ceramics for daily use (including bowls and cups) to traditional tea utensils and flower vases. In this program, you can... ・ Get a detailed explanation in Japanese pottery and how Minoyaki is crafted. ・ Go and enjoy shopping! (Mino-yaki style pottery is one of the best Gifu souvenirs).
strTitle: Learn about Minoyaki Pottery

strIntroduction: Welcome to Samurai Town, Kamakura. In the 12th century, Japan’s first full-fledged military government was established in Kamakura. Still now you can feel samurai power at its historic sites, such as the magnificent Tsurugaoka Hachiman Shrine, Hasedera temple (noted for a wide variety of flowers) and the Great Buddha.! You’ll be walking quite a bit, so we recommend you wear a comfortable pair of walking shoes. We will also explore and eat the lunch on the Komachi street. The lunch is not included in this tour.
strTitle: Samurai City Kamakura Tour

strIntroduction: Kamakura is a famous tourist spot and a short trip from Tokyo. It is located less than an hour south of Tokyo by train. There are many zen temples and shrines surrounded by great natural areas. I can assist your kamakura trip to make it more fun and easier than traveling alone. There are many Japanese tourists, many complicated buses, but you will have an easier time traveling with me. There are many highlights in Kamakura! Some examples: ・Walk around famous zen temples in Kita Kamakura ・Visit the world-famous Great Buddha ・Walk a hiking course ・Visit Kirido-shi(Old path) ・Attend Zazen meditation (as the situation allows) ・Try Syakyo (as the situation allows) I can arrange the tour based on your request. We can meet at the Kamakura or Kita Kamakura station.
strTitle: Kamakura Private Walking Tour

strIntroduction: As the old saying goes, a picture is worth a thousand words. This activity will make your trip to Tokyo even more memorable with your very own hand-made mini album of unforgettable moments! The host will meet you at Azabujuban station/the studio. In this 2-hour workshop, you will learn how to combine images with words, and get ideas and inspiration on how to collect and organize your scraps in a creative way! If you have any memorable paper items collected during your trip (e.g. used train tickets, paper packages, photos etc), please bring them along for the workshop. But don't worry even if you don't have any. What can you make? You will learn several book binding techniques such as Japanese stab binding, Star book binding, Japanese folding book method. You will also be inspired by creative and easy ways to capture your precious travel memories. By the end of the workshop, you will have created your own mini album/journal to bring along on your future travel adventures!
strTitle: Create a Mini Album - Capture Your Journey in Tokyo

strIntroduction: Kichijoij is conveniently located just 20mins away from Shinjuku and Shibuya station. There are plenty of fancy shops and funky people here. The lush and relaxing Inokashira Park also sits right beside this area. Kichijoji has been ranked number 1 "most popular place to live in Tokyo!" Come join us on a tour of the blind alleyways in Tokyo! Our guides speak fluent English, so you won't have to worry about a language barrier! First, we will arrange a customized journey for you based on what you what to experience. You can basically follow us around Kichijoji and see life as a local. We can visit the bustling blind alleys afterwards and visit the tranquil Inokashira Park. Stock up on snacks at the start of the trip! Next, you can choose from the following optional tours: -Eat Ramen noodle for lunch -Sit on a swan-shaped boat in Inokashira pond -Visit the famous Ghibli Museum -Relax at a famous public bath -Night pub crawl Some of these tours require advance reservation, so do book early to let us know Some Highlights of the tour: ■Hamonica yokocho - Great blind alley with local food and traditional bars. Good for shopping and pub crawls ■Inokashira park and temples - Walk around and relax over coffee at a fancy cafe. ■Benten-yu Public bath ■The Ghibli Museum - The most famous animation studio *Please book at least 2 weeks in advance if you would like to go on the Ghibli Tour. Here is a sample itinerary: 13:00: Meet at Kichijoji station 13:30: Go to Inokashira park. Take a picture with the traditional temples in the park 15:00: Take a short break at fancy forest cafe 15:30: Window shopping on Sun-Road street 16:00: Visit Hamonica-Yokocho bazaar 16:30: Walk around and buy popular snacks 17:00: Back to Kichijoji station Note that above itinerary is just a sample, and all of our tours are customized. Feel free ask us what you would like to do (what type of trip, duration, cost, food preferences)! We can arrange private tour just for you! There are many different and unique experiences available in Kichijoji, apart from typical tours that only bring you to famous places in Tokyo! I hope you won't miss this tour to enjoy the real Tokyo. We look forward to meeting you soon!
strTitle: Pop Round & Check Out the Best “Blind Alley” of Tokyo!

strIntroduction: In this activity, I'll pick out clothes, shoes, glasses and other accessories that will best fit you. You'll learn tips on choosing a style for any occasion. I look forward to shop with you! This activity is provided for English and Chinese speaking people who have an interest in the latest Japanese trends or would like to know more about a particular style of interest. ※If you want to join this activity with friends, let me know in advance and I'll make the proper arrangements!
strTitle: Shopping in Tokyo with a Stylist

strIntroduction: are you looking for an artistic and creative activity? Enjoy an amazing and memorable experience of creating Japanese Sumiganashi art at our studio. (Suminagashi is an ancient Japanese technique for decorating paper with inks.) What can you make? You will be able to create 5 -10 greeting cards and/or gift tags with beautiful Sumiganashi pattern to bring home. The facilitator will meet you at Azabujuban station / the studio, please come with empty hands and a playful heart! NO art experience is required. It will be your private session, kids, couples, families are all welcome!
strTitle: 2-Hour Japanese Suminagashi Creation in Tokyo

strIntroduction: Hot springs have been a favorite tradition in Japan for a long time. No matter the season in Japan, a good bath is essential to soothing a hard day’s worth of work. And regardless of age, many visit hot springs for the countless health benefits. There are so many hot springs in Japan but out of the many, “Kusatsu” and “Hakone are probably the most well-known. These are difficult to get to if you live in Tokyo though. So in this activity, you can go to five different hot springs in “Minato-mirai” - all in one large facility - in Yokohama, which is only 30 minutes away from Tokyo. Or you will go to the same hot springs in Tokyo! To speak in more detail, you can do the following in this activity: • Borrow and wear traditional Japanese clothes (ex. Yukata) • Enjoy a “hinoki (Japanese Cypress) bath” • Take a bath in a hot spring modeled after a garden. • Take a footbath, where you can see an incredible night view. Enjoy a hot spring when you visit Japan, and take a break from the daily stress you may be feeling – unwind your body and give your mind a vacation in this almost heavenly activity.
strTitle: Visit an Onsen Theme Park in Machida/Yokohama

strIntroduction: In this activity designed for intermediate, you will learn how to dye and draw using a traditional Japanese method called "Yuzen-zomé" on a handkerchief or coaster. Your instructor is Kiichiro Fujiki, who has been a Yuzen dyer for 55 years and now collaborates with Disney on projects. He has also dyed and designed many delicate but vibrant kimonos for films. To give you a brief history of the craft, "Yuzen-zomé" was originally started by Yuzensai Miyazaki about 300 years ago in Kyoto. The beautiful and elaborate Yuzen-dyed kimonos were a colorful element of Geisha culture during the Edo era. Today, "Yuzen-zomé" is still very popular and is sought after by many people. In the intermediate course, Fujiki-san will show you how to make your own two Tenugui (Japanese hand towels). You can use your favorite colors to express yourself. Intermediate class offers dyeing and painting as well. -- All finished products will serve as your souvenir of this unique experience.
strTitle: Take an Intermediate Lesson on Dyeing Fabric

strIntroduction: Over 400 years ago in the Muromachi period, water painting – a traditional type of painting - spread from China to Japan. Water painting normally is painted using only ink expressing a variety of pictures through shading. In this activity, you will be taught how to paint traditional Chinese water painting – the home of water painting – in an easy-to-follow manner. You will… • Learn easy ink painting techniques that enable you to freely paint a black and white Monochrome world. • Learn how to draw basic pictures of bamboo, orchid, and plum as well as applying that technique to draw animals, buildings and seasonal flowers in an easy-to-follow lesson. We will then have your paintings printed on colored paper or on a scroll for you to take back as souvenirs. In a small group, enjoy a full experience of the world of ink painting!
strTitle: Learn Traditional Chinese and Japanese Water Painting

strIntroduction: Are you interested in talking about serious topics - politics, history, and career paths et cetera? If you are, and would like to spend a day immersing yourself in Japanese culture through casual conversations rather than sightseeing, I am a perfect companion for you! If you want to know about specific topics, let me know in advance! I will do my research beforehand and be ready for mind-enriching discussions with you!
strTitle: Chat over Coffee with a Japanese Business Woman

strIntroduction: “Furins” a.k.a. wind chimes originated in the “heian period”(794-1185) in Japan. It is said in literature that in the “Kamakura”period (1185-1333), the nobility hung wind chimes in their porches to keep misfortune out of their houses. Today, wind chimes are considered a summer tradition. They are hung in porches for the clear high pitched sound that is produced when the wind rattles the small bell in the wind chime. The sound reminds people that there’s a cool breeze outside – almost getting people to feel like they’re in that breeze. In this activity you will learn how to make an “Edo Furin”. You will... •Watch the host make an “Edo Furin” •Hear an explanation of the host’s everyday work followed by time for questions. •Inflate glass by blowing into it with a hollow metal rod (The host will help, no worries!) •Paint on the inflated glass after it has cooled down (This will take around 15min) •Attach string and bell after you finish painting. •The wind chime will then be put into a box for you to take back! You will feel the very spirit of Japan from the wind chimes that each makes a different sound. Take back traditional Japanese craftwork as a souvenir!
strTitle: Learn How to Make an Edo Wind Chime in Tokyo
